title: Whichford Wood Walking Route

images.title: Graham Horn / Bluebells in Whichford Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bluebells in Whichford Wood. At their peak, 28th April 2007. Whichford Wood has hundreds of bluebell spots like this and many paths to see them from, so is very popular with walkers.

images.title: Graham Horn / Path towards Whichford Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path towards Whichford Wood. A footpath from Long Compton climbs gradually towards the woods, the western extremity of which is seen here.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Towards Whichford Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bridleway from Great Rollright, having ascended from the valley bottom, levels out as it approaches the wood.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Footpath in Whichford Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath in Whichford Wood. The Macmillan Way long distance footpath descends through Whichford Wood from the junction with the bridleway. The Macmillan Way continues to the right of the image whilst the bridleway goes to the right of the image up to the minor road.

images.title: Graham Horn / Along the top of Whichford Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Along the top of the woods. A good bridleway skirts the southern edge of Whichford Wood, providing excellent walking and riding. This is part of the Macmillan Way long distance path.

images.title: Graham Horn / Track in Whichford Woods, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of a number of excellent bridleways and footpath through Whichford Woods. Very popular in the spring, but probably quite muddy in winter.

description: Enjoy a short, peaceful stroll through these delightful woods on the edge of the Cotswolds. The area consists of Broadleaved and conifer woodland with a number of woodland walking trails to try. There are lovely views over the surrounding Warwickshire countryside from the forest too. Look out for various wildflowers, bluebells and wildlife including fallow deer. After your walk you can enjoy refreshments at the pub in the village of Whichford. The Macmillan Way long distance footpath runs through the woods so you could pick this up to extend your walk through Long Compton Woods to the village of Long Compton. If you continue south you will soon come to the fascinating Rollright Stones . The group of Neolithic and Bronze Age megalithic monuments consists of three groups of stones: the King's Men stone circle, the Whispering Knights burial chamber and the single King Stone.
